table.head: OTHER STATIONS.
For the 24 hours ending 3 a.m. Yesterday

div.head: The Russian Disaster
div.p: If it be true that "dark's the hour before the dawn," then Russia should be about to enjoy a sunrise of unprecendented splendour, for never, surely, has the night of her mis- fortunes been blacker, or the winter of her

discontent more severse. East and WEst, at home and in Manchuria, the future s equally shrouded in impenetrable gloom, and such speculations as it is possible to make con- cerning the course of events only seem to create that "darkness visible" which Milton imagined as the only light in Hell. Little by little we are learning what the vast Japanese host beyond the Sha-ho has succeeses in doing. Time has fought on the side of the commander nearest to his base. As everybody might, surely, have seen (but as curiously, many did not see), Russia never had a serious chance of bringing more ment into the field than Japan. And the release of Nogi's force before Port Arthur has effectually decided the question of numbers. Oyama, confident in numerical, as well as other, superiority, has acheieved a great enveloping movement and inflicted on the Russian Army the more crushing defeat of the war. The telegrams to-day form gruesome reading. Official despatches record the loss of nearly 500 guns and over 200,000 men. Ge- neral Kuropatkin, telegraphing on the 11th inst., admits that out of two regiments there were only 150 and 619 survivors respectively. The Russian dead, we are told,were everywhere, and from the 28th February to the 11th inst. 47,581 wounded were sout North. Apparently, the First Army alone is intact, the where- abouts and condition of the remainder being quite incertain. It is doubtful, says Reuter, if the remains of the shattered armies are capable of holding out, if the pursuit is pressed more. The position of the Russian Army is therefore obviously one of utter desperation. Kuropatkin has been deprived of that last blessing, an alternative. As seems in the highest degree probable, if the Japanese tactics prove suc- cessful, his retreat from Mukden will be cut off, and all that will remain will be standing still and - surrendering. In little over a day the complexion of affairs has changed. The retire- ment on Harbin has been rendered almost impossible. Probably it is quite impossible by this time. Kuroki has driven in the left flank, Nodzu is forcing back the centre, Oku and Nogi are trespassing on the right, while a strong Japanese force has obtained pos- session of the Harbin road. The Russians fight bravery - much more bravely than might have been predicted. Either they have not credited the news from the interior or their country, or they are not in so revolu- tionary a frame of mind as the reformers would have us believe. It is impossible to suppose that the fight between the Tsar and his people has had any efect on their military prowess. After all, the simple explanation may be that a Russian soldier can attend to only one thing at a time, and Kuropatkin's men have been deafened to all other considera- tions by the roar of the Japanese guns, accou- panied as it is by an insuffciency of food and by the horro of utter discouragement. The Russian soldier is the outstanding tragic item in the situation though no one bestows much thought on him.

div.head: Cape to Cairo Telegraph
div.p: Great progress has lately been made with the Cape to Cairo telgraph, which has reach- ed the little German settlement of Ujiji, on the eastern shores of Lake Tanganyika, and about 300 miles north of the extreme limit of British territory in the couthern portion of Central Africa. Arrangements are now all but completed for the commencement of a further considerable section of the line along the eastern shores of the Victoria Nyanza; and thence the line will be taken due north to Rosares, where it will be connected with the Sudanese telegraph system. It is thought that the line will be open from end to end by the end of 1906.

div.head: The Cotton Trade in Lancashire
div.p: Writing in the "Financier" of the 4th inst., Mr. W. Tattersall stated that the cotton trade in Lancashire was in a state of unexampled prosperity, excepting the fine yarn department. "Every day," he continued, "we have reports in the papers of proposals to erect weaving sheds in different parts of Lancashire. Co- operative provision societies are offering help in sevral cases. No doubt there are at the present time a fair number of sheds going up, and if the list proposed goes thorugh there will be by the end of the year a moderate increase in the number of looms. The question arises - Where are the operative weavers to come from to fill these new places I At present there is a scarcity of this kind of labour,"

div.head: The Russian Rout. Enormous Losses 500 Guns Abandoned Casualties 200,000 PRECIPITATE FLIGHT
div.p: St. Petersburg, March 13. Official despatches record the loss of nearly 1 500 guns and over 200,000 men. ^

Kurnjiatkin, cabling daring the evening of 1 the 1 ltb inst., states :—“Am accompanying the 1 Second Army. The enemy to-day only attacked ; the rearguard of the Third Siberian Corps. Portions of the First Array were this morning 15 to 20 miles from Tieling. The Third Army ( Corps on the Mandariu road was 16 miles from ' Tieling. Its rearguard was confronted by only • a small force, mostly of cavalry. 47,581 wound- 1 ed have been sent north from the 28th
February to the 11th March.” (Reuter.) 1 i
Tokio, March 13.

According to further despatches from Oyama, from noon on Friday countless thou- ■ sands of Russians were retreating north in a 1 miserable condition, in great confusion and ( utterly exhausted. They filled the district be- 4 tween the railway and the Tieling road. The ^ Japanese artillery and infantry which were iu 1 the vicinity have been pouring in a fierce fire, 8 inflicting heavy damage.

(Saturday night). The whole of the Japanese forces were over the Hun-Ho on the 10th inst c vigorously pursuing the enemy. Tho pursnit 1 was continued on the 11th, near Mukden, the ' Japanese clearing out the remnant of the enemy who continued to resist or surrendered in masses. ‘
The Russian dead were everywhere.

(Sunday's despatch). When cabling, the Japanese bad captured al58ut 60 guns, , 200,000 shells, and 25,000,000 cartridges, to- J gother with immense stores. The Eastern ( Armies’ captures were not reported. The f prisoners include Geueral Nakhimofi. (Reuter.') j

St. Petersburg, March 13. j General Kuropatkin, telegraphing ou the 11th inst, admits huviug had 50,000 men * wounded. He says that the retreat was mast arduous, the country being intersected by rivers and steep bunks, where the wagg-m* were 1 only able to cross singly. The Japanese were - constantly reinforced and continuously cannon- L aded tho Russians. Uonoral Kuropatkin men- , tions that out of two regimeuts there were only 150 and 618 survivors respectively. (R.)1
London, March 13. ^

The pursuit was continued during the whole of yesterday, the Russians abandoning gunB aud supplies iu their wild fright Apparently < tho First Army alone is intact, the where- I abouts and condition of the remainder being ] quite uncertain. It is doubtful if the remnants 1 of tho shattered armies are capable of holding < out if the pursuit is pressed home. (Reuter.)
Tokio, March 13. 1
The Japanese have made more than 40,000 ' prisoners, among whom is General Nakbimoff.
(Hanot.)
Tieling, March 13. ]
The Russians are beginning to arrive here, j The Japanese arc advancing slowly. (Havae. i
London, March 13. I
The newspapers emphasise the stupendous i significance of the battle upon the history of < the world. I

The "Standard” says there will be grave i searchings of tho heart in Germany, which has J so studiously consulted the ambitions of Russia and stubbornly opposed every advance of Japan. Great Britain rejoices unreservedly in the success of the people with whom she is ' associated by alliance aud by ties of common interest and sympathy.

div.head: Kuropatkin in Want of a Rest Asks for Transfer of Command
div.p: London, March 13.
The "Times" learns from St. Petersburg that Kuropatkin has asked the Emperor’s penuis sion to transfer his command, owing to his .need of rest. (Reuter.)
St, Petersburg, March 13.
The newspapers state that General Ktiro- patkin has asked to be relieved of his command. He will be replaced by General Sonkhomlinoff.
(Havat.)

div.head: Building Land for Sale
div.p: On the road to Guzizeh. Price L.E. 4,000 Write: P.B. Poste Kestante

div.head: LOCAL AND General
div.p: The Annual Horticultural Show will take placo at Gbezireh on the 25th and 26th inst.
Liberation of Slaves.—During the month of February 6 slaves were freed, 3 Sudanese at Assouan and 3 Sudanese women at Cairo.
The Plague.—During the week ending the 1 ltb inst., only one case of plague was report­ed throughout Egypt. It occurred in tho Toukh district
St. Mark’s Church.—We may remind our readers that the adjourned meeting of voters , of St. Mark’s Church, Alexandria, will take ; place at H.B.M.'s Consulate on Thursday, 16th . inst., at 5 p.m.

Suez Canal.— Ou tho 10th inst. 17 vessels , passed through the Canal, 11 of which were British, 2 German, 2 French, 1 Austrian, 1 , Russian. The day's receipts were fre.403,696,19, , making the total from the 1st inst. frs. ] 3,116,900.29.

Alhambra Theatre,—We understand that \ the ‘ revue’’ entitled AUxcmdrie en Bairn, \ by M. George R&lli, will be staged at the , Alhambra this week. The properties of the { production, to which an additional’interest will be added by ballets, are said to be on a grand scale. We shall in due course give the date of the opening performance.

H.M. Transport "Soudan” (Capt. S. de B. Lockyer) reached Port Said on Sunday after* noon with 1,206 troops from Bombay. A draft of the Royal Garrison Artillery and a few J details, numbering about 25Q, embarked at Port Said. Major Goodwin is the officer com- I manding. The “Soudan” left for Southampton at midnight

New Hospital at Old Cairo.— A notice ' of the "Ethel Pain Memorial Hospital,” which | the C.M.S. intend to build in Old Cairo, was 1 recently published in the "Egyptian Gazette." 1 The foundation stone of the building is to be laid on Friday next by Sir Algernon Coote, Bart, at 4 p.m. The Right Rev. Bishop Blyth will conduct tho service.

Anglo-American Hospital. — Sir Hugh Smiley has bestowed a donation of £1,000 ' on the Anglo-American Hospital at Cairo for * the perpetual endowment of a free bed at that hospital. The news of this generous gift h^i been received with great pleasure by the British community at Cairo and it is hoped that Sir Hugh will find many to emulate his j generosity.

St. Mary's Schools, Cairo.—An entertain- j mont is to be given by the pupils of the girls' ( school on Monday, 20th inst., from 3 to 5 p.m. The programme includes an English operetta ( "The Fairy Chain,” aud a French operetta, "Marquise et Duchesse,” besides songs and , recitations. The Earl and Countess of Cromer are expected to be present, as also Btihop Blyth.

Savot 1 lom.—The Savoy Hotel at Cairo will ' continue to give a dauce every Saturday until < the 15th April, owing to the large number of people who have decided to stay in Cairo until the middle of next month. The small dance on Saturday last was a greet suooees. The ex-Empress Eugenie and her suite are return­ing to the Savoy from Upper Egypt on the 17th inst. The ex-Empress will remain there until the end of the month.

An Interview with Maxim Gorki.—The celebrated Russian writer, on his release from prison, was interviewed by an English journalist. After having given his opinion upon the condition of affairs in Russia, Gorki ended by oxpressing bis regret at not knowing foreign languages. Such a regret would be superfluous if Gorki lived in Egypt or auy other country in which there is a Berlitz School, for in a few months be wonld succeed in becoming fairly acquainted with any language. 25589-1

Merchant Seamen’s Home. — The usual weekly ooncert was held on Friday evening lost, before a crowded audienoe of seamen and friends from towu who bad dooked to eqjoy the treat in store lor them. The Rev. if. F. Reid presided. The attraction of the evening was the renowned entertainer, Mr. Scott-Loslie, whose funny songs and stories caused much mirth, aud were rapturously encored. Mr. D.E. Norton played two beautiful pianoforte solos, and also aooompanied all the tongs. Mr. John­son’s magnificent and well-trained voioe showed to advantage in “The Lute Flayer” and “Yeo­men of England," and being encored, be sang “Girlene” with much feeling. Mr. Percy Smith, a general favorite, gave "The Silver Cup” and "True till Death” with very great pathos. Mr. Samson’s parodies on "Love's old sweet Sung” aud “InOld Madrid” were very amusiug, and as an encore he sang another on '•Tom Bowl­ing." Mr. J. Purvis’ songs were well tendered, and in response to "The Last Master" he sang “When the boys come marching home,” the chorus being vigorously taken up by all Miss MuuGavin’s fine rendering of "Beloved, it is Morn” and "The Promise of Life” fairly "brought down” the house. Being recalled, she gave “Huskeen” with great finish. Mia.

J. E. Roberts rang “The way thro' the wood” and “Katey’s Letter” very tastefully, aud de­served tbo warm applause she received. Mr. W. F. Ear]cant saug (by special request) "The Ghost of a Cook” with his accustomed ^biiity. He is to be oongretulsted on arranging such a delightful concert, which was one of the best given this season at the Jfoa*

div.head: Alexandria to Trieste Voyage to be reduced by one day
div.p: (From our Correspondent).
Constantinople, March 7:

M. Beshor, president of tEe board of the Austrian Lloyd 3.8, Co., M. Vivsute, member of the board ol administration, and M. Brosh, commercial sub-manager of the company, are now in Vienna, negotiating with the Austrian Government regarding the change which is to be made in the itinerary of the vessels running between Alexandria and Trieste.' The duration of the voyage is now three and a half days, and it is intended to reduce it to only two and a Unit days.

It is announced that Colonel Coanda, of the Roumanian Steamship Company, baa made a most favorable report to the Ministry of Public Works at Bucharest on the establishment of a new Hue between Constantinople, Pineus, and Alexandria. Colonel Coanda is now at Bucharest.

The betrothal is officially announced of Mile. Yvonne Provost, sister of M. Fernand Provost, formerly secretary of the French Embassy here, and now of the French Diplomatic Agency at Cairo, with M. Boppe, French Consul-General at Beyront.

div.head: The Sirdar at Suakin
div.p: Suakin, March 7.

Sir Reginald Wingate, Governor-General of the Sudan, and his Staff, arrived at Suakin this morning by train from railhead, acecom- panied by Howard Bey, the Governor of Sua­kin, who met hiA Excellency at Thamiam. The party was received at the town gate by the civil and military officials and tbe principal inhabitants. Sir Reginald Wingate will hold a levee and make inquiries into various matters. He will leave on Thursday morning for Suez by tho steamer "Abd-el-Moneim,” calling at Sheikh Barghout, the new port of the Sudan, to make an inspection.—Renter.
Sir F. R, Wingate arrived at Cairo from Suakin vesterdav.

div.head: Troops for Suakin
div.p: Half the 6th Battalion will leave Cairo for Suez at 7 a.m. on Thursday next, and will embark at that port for Suakin.

div.head: A Bank of Abyssinia
div.p: Tho following Reuter’s telegram has been published in the home papers :—An interna­tional bank is about to be founded at Adis Abob.i, in Abyssinia, with a capital of £480,000. Half this sum is to be contributed by the Bank of K,'ypt, one fourth by French hanks, and the remainder by Italian banks. The Italian Government will not enter into the combination.
On enquiry at the Alexandria offices of the Bank of Egypt we were informed that nothing was known there with regard to that bank's participation in tbe scheme.

A correspondent, writing from Adis Abeba on the 11th ulto., says :—Ah agent of Messrs. Cassel is expected here in the course of a few days, having been sent by them to report on the practicability of the establishment of a State bank. It is through the advice of Sir John Harrington, the British Minister, that tho Emperor has entertained this scheme, but it is generally understood here that Sir John has strongly doprecated the idea of making the bank anything but a thoroughly cosmopo­litan one, giving equal opportunity to all the Powers interested iu the country to acquire a share in the undertaking.

div.head: The Egyptian Frontier
div.p: The Gnlf of Solum, where the Turkish fron­tier post has established itself on the Egyptian side of the boundary, is about 100 miles west of Marea Matrouh. Its importance is not great, though we believe that one time it was the centre of a certain amount ot smuggling of firearmB which found their way into the interior of Tripoli and the Libyan Desert, after being landed at Jeijub on the E. side of the bay. One of the routes to Siwa starts from Jeijub, passing the interesting ruins of Kasr el Ajdebiah and crossing the coastal plateau to the oasis. We beUeve that the frontier has never been delimitated, nor have any very accnr&te maps of the desert country near the Gnlf of Solum been published.

div.head: Departure of Gen. Slade Farewell at Cairo Station
div.p: A few minn tee after 11 o'clock this morning Major-General Slade, C.B., with Mrs. and Min Slade, left Cairo for Port Said. A great sum ber of friends, with ail the principal officera of the Army of Occupation and of the Egyptian forces, were present at the station to bid good­bye to the gallant General and his wife and daughter, who, during their stay in Cairo, have enjoyed the esteem and respect of the whole British- community, both civil and military. Among those present we may mention Lady Cromer, Lady Bea­trice Thynne, Sir F. R. and lavdy Wingate, Brig.-Gen. Bullock, Mr. and Mrs. M. do C. Findlay, Sir John and Lady Rogers, Sir Elwin and Lady Palmar, CoL Mbtohett, Col. Friend, Mr. and Mrs. Alban, Crooksbank Pasha and Mrs. Crooksbank, and many others. A guard of honour, which gave a general salute, was drawn from the Royal Inniskilling Fusiliers, and the Egyptian Army was also represented. As the train left the station, the band played “Homeward Bound." The farewell was most cordial, and great regret wu expressed at the gallant and distinguished General’s departure.

div.head: THE KHEDIVE.
div.p: The Khedive who is at present spending his time between Montazah and Mariout, is expected to return to the Capital on Thursday.

The King has been pleased to give and grant onto William Edwin Branyate, Esq., Khedivial Councillor in the Egyptian Ministry of Justice, bis Majesty's Royal licence aud authority that he may accept and wear the Insignia of the 8eoood Class of the Imperial Ottoman Order of the Osmanieb, conferred upon him by bis Highness the Khedive oi Egypt, authorised by his Imperial Majesty the Sultan otitfurkey, in recognition of valuable services rendered to bis Highness.

The Kirig has been pleased to give and grant unto George Pearse Foaden, Esq.. So cretary-General to the Khedivial Agricultural Society, his Majesty's Royal licenoe and author ity that he may accept and wear the Insignia of the Second Class of the Imperial Ottoman Order of the Medjidieh, conferred upon him bj his Highness the Khedive of Egypt, authorised by bis imperial Majesty the Sultan of Turkey, in recognition of valuable services rendered tc his Highness.

The King has been pleased to give and grant onto Michael Iaw, Esq., Judge in the Egyptian Mixed Tribunals, his Majesty’t Royal licenoe and authority that he may so cept and wear the Insignia of the Second Glass ol the Imperial Ottoman Order of the Medji dieh, conferred upon him by his Highness the Khedive of Egypt, authorised by his Imperial Majesty the Sultan of Turkey, in reoognitiot of valuable services rendered to his Highness

The King has been pleased to give and grant unto Herbert Augustas Hills, Esq., late Judge in the Egyptian Mixed Court of Appeal at Alexandria, bis Majesty’s Royal licence and authority that he may accept and wear the Insignia of the Seooud Class of the Imperial Ottoman Older of the Medjidieh, conferred npou him by his Highness the Khedive cA E.'ypt, authorised by bis Imperial Majesty the Sultan of Turkey, in recognition of va­luable aorvioe* rendered to bis Highness.

div.head: Motor Accient at Mena
div.p: A motor, while coming from the garden of Mena House on Sunday, ran over a little norite donkey boy of about 8 years. The boy was seriously hurt, having a fracture of the shoulder and one arm broken. Drs. Milton and Wake- ling, who happened to be on the spot, ad­ministered first aid. The boy was taken to Dt. Milton's Hospital, but there is little hope of his recovery.

A correspondent write*"Motorcars should really not be allowed to drive through the gates of Mena, for in addition to being a greet nuisance to visitors taking their tea on the terrace of the hotel, they are a constant danger to any one on the road outside the gates, and it is a wonder that accidents have not happen­ed before- It is impossible for a motor driver to see what is going on in the road, when he starts inside the gates in front oi the terraae, and as they generally do not leave at a slow pace, they upset the whole traffic outside. A notice has been put up by the management of the hotel to prevent automobiles entering the grounds, but nobody seems to pay any heed |to it. The police, who are stationed opposite tho hotel, should certainly lend their assistance to stop the nuisance.”

div.head: P&O Company
div.p: Wa are desired to state that the P. & 0. Company's main line steamers to ManUUes regularly leave Port Said at 5 p.m. every Monday after the arrival of the 11 o’olock morning train from Cairo, and a steam tender awaits the train to convey passengers on board.

div.head: Matarieh Railway Line The Electrification Project
div.p: The negotiations between the-Belgian finan­cial group and the Bfeyptian Government in regard to the electrification of the 'Matarieh railway line are now at a standstill. The reason is that the Deha Light Railway Com­pany have also m*ie an offer to the Govern­ment to undertake the Work. Negotiations may, however, be resumed on another basis. According to this project, a new line may be ooestrwotod to the Matsriab Oasis, starting from a oentnl point in Cairo, and going by way of ths Abbas Boulevard.

div.head: The Menzaleh Company
div.p: The negotiations between the Menzaleh Company and the Suez Canal Company for opening communication with the 8uez Canal are poetically completed.
The Menzaleh company's fleet is now ondei construction at K&rpooty.
The new dredger, made by the well-known English fins of Gwynne, has arrived and ii now being put together at Karpouty.

div.head: Nungovich Hotels Co.
div.p: The Egyptian Railway Administration, the Suez Canal Company, and the Nungoyich Hotels Co. have come to an agreement in ( regard to the proposed terminal hotel at Port 8aid. The Ekilway Administration is to give the site and the Canal Company will advance the funds for the construction, while the Nun- govioh Hotels Co. will rent and manage the i hotel.

The reoeipta of the Nnngovioh Co. from the l Cairo and Helouan hotels this season have, up , to date, been By far the greatest ever gained in f any season since this successful hotel company 1 started.

div.head: Wreck of the "Zareef"
div.p: The master and officers of the S.S. “Zareef,” whose stranding off the coast we announced yes­terday, are to appear at the British Consulate this afternoon to swear an affidavit, the 1 vessel being under the British flag.
The captain and men's account of the j disaster is that the ship had a pontoon in tow * for Port Said, and that about 8 o'clock on

Sunday night she sprang a leak and three hour* , afterwards got entirely full ot water, eo that master and crew had to abandon her and save j their lives on board the pontoon, where they remained rill 6 o’clock next morning. Then they q were picked up by an Arab fisherman, who brought them into the harbour in his boat. 4 They have lost everything, including their

div.head: The S.S. "Cairo"
div.p: The Florio-Rubattino S.8. “Cairo" Hes in ) the same position. The rongh sea which has j prevailed has precluded all attempts at re- 1 floating her. Salvage operations were being carried out this morning.

div.head: STEAMER MOVEMENTS
div.p: Although the S.S. "HoheczoUern,” of the Noiddeutacber Lloyd, left Marseilles on the 9th inst. at 6:45 am., having been detained 18 bonis in the harbour owing to bad weather, the steamer arrived at Alexandria punctually at 3 p.m. yesterday, after a very good passage. The steamer is berthed at quay No. 81 and will kavei as usual, on Wednesday at 5 p.m. with about 130 passengers for Naples and Marseilles.
The KUannsn S.S, "Adalia,” now in port, Will begin loading forManchetiWOO Thursday.
The Weetoott S.S. “Egypti-vu” arrived to­day from Antwerp, London, and Malta with passengers, mails, and general cargo.
The Westoott SB. “Bulgarian” sailed from London on the 4th inst. for Malta and Alex­andria.
The BUerman S.S. "Athenian” sailed from Malta on Monday evening and is expected to arrive here on Friday morning with general cargo.
The Khedivial Mail ,6,8. “El Kobira" will leave Alexandria on Saturday and Poet Said on Sunday for Jaffa, Coifla, Beyront, Tripoli, limba, Alexandria, Ureaoa, and LimaeeoJ,

div.head: PERSONAL AND Social
div.p: Prince Adalbert of Prussia returned to Port Said from Cairo on Sunday afternoon and rejoined the orojeer “nartjia, ‘ left yesterday morning for the Kraus.

Fakhty Pasha, Minister of Public Works, will give a dinner on Tuesday, 21st Inst, at the Gbepreh Palace Hotel. Among t&iioo guests invited are thb Minister*, and Undef-Eecretaries of State, the heads of departments, arid the member* of the Diplo­matic. Corps. _____
Mr. and the Hon. Mr*. Rookfoct MagMre, who have ben staying at the Savoy Betel, left Cairo yesterday for owing to
having received news of the iadfeposikion of Mra. Maguire's father, Viscount Peek

Mr. and Mrs. Monroe Coats, who have heap Staying at the Savoy Hotel for over two entertained a party to dinner in one of the private dining-rooms adjacent to the Savoy Restaurant yesterday evening. The gvwete included: Count and Counteas WedM, Prinoe Oettingen,Misses Hurley,Count Kodriebrodtki, Count ChamarC, and’ Mr. and 'Mrs. Jamas Coats.
8ir Ernest Cassel’s party at the Savqy Res­taurant yesterday evening included Lord Howe, Fabricate Pacha and Mine Fabriclus, Sit Edward and Lady Colebrooke, and Mr. Vincent Corbet _____

Moubeb Bey, the popular Moudir of the Fayoum, definitely left Medinet el-Fhyowm on 8unday in order to take up his new peat at Zagazig as Moudir of the Skarkfeh Province. But before going to Kagatig the Moudir is staying for a short time at the Grand Conti­nental Hotel, Cairo.

The Moudir’i tenure of office >t Mnitiuttl el Fayoum has been very successful, and tbs establishment of a Municipality at that town is in great measure due to his energy and teat The opposition to the establishment of such an institution was at the outset very keen, but the late Moudir overcame all obstacle*, and prior to his departure the member* of the Municipality unanimously voted him an ad­dress of thanks and gave a fete on his gajng away. The members of the Municipality alio voted a sum for having a portrait of Moiheb Bey painted and sad up in their council cham­ber, so that the Municipality might have a permanent memento of its founder.

div.head: The Anglo-Egyptian Sudan
div.p: Mr, W, W. A. Fitzgerald gave an interesting lecture at Coxton Hall, Westminster, last week under tbo auspices of the League of the Em­pire, ou "The Anglo-Egyptian Sudan—Gordon's trust." Sir Charles Lyall, who presided, ex­plained that the objects oi the league, which was established three years ago, wore to in­spire personal and active interest in the Empire, and to promote educational and friendly intercommunication between its diffe- rent parts. It was just twenty years and a month ago that General Gordon died, and the great work ot civilisation which bail since been nooutuplUbetl would bo described by Mr. Fits- Coraid. After remarking that no not of Gor­don's life could have drawn Great Britain to the completion 61 hi* groat task iu the Sudan to much as his death, and that Dervish mis­rule and anarchy had muro limn justified the uuipdgn which had brought the country under tho British and Egyptian flags, the lecturer excited tho interest of the audience by giving a series ol views of the country, the pcoplo, and tho Blue and Whito Mile, a hich enabled him to show that Gordon had not died in vein. Tbo journey betwoeu Cairo and Khartoum across an unknown, dangerous, and Waterless desort could now be covored in perfect safety and comfort in loss than four Jays by the aid of the railway constructed under the orders of Ljrd Kitchener in his Lm-iu<*rablo campaign. Pictures of the railway, the desert, tho groat barrage works on the Mile, and the other engineering triumphs achieved in the sudd regions, formed a fitting introduction to views of Oinduriufcn and Khar* louts, with the Mshdi's tomb and tho Go- pernor General» palaoe. Tho greatest interest wntred on the illustrations given of the iurdou Collego, founded by Lord Kitchener For tho education of the young people of the Sudan : of Gordon's rose trot) iu the a lace garden and of the hero's memorial >tatu*. Tbo looturor incidentally mentioned that, among others, the son of tho late K hah fa was learning (be trade of a car- Muter, which ho preferred* to going to school. After describing the progress towards civilisa­tion which was being made by the Arabs n the dry rout*, and the Negroes in the set and tropiosl parts of the country, Mr. r'itzgendd said that it Gordon could now see be Sudan he would know that England hud Invert to do her duty towards it. His statue ras her last pledge that British rule would i id are, and J list the prospects of the country ronld grow brighter and better as the years oiled on. (Applause).

div.head: LETTERS to the Editor
div.p: CRUELTY TO BIRDS.

To rni; Eniimt or the ‘‘Eovptian Gazetvx" Dear Sir,—May I venture in the columns of your valuable paper to call the attention of , the travelling publio to the distressing cruel­ties that aro to be seen practised towards birds', at some of the stations touched at by the ?leamcrs going up and down-the Nile, arising, so I am told, from tourists and others having given money in order to release the poor victims-*- this, of course, is obviously fatal. Birds with broken wings and leg* and with wing feathers palled out, strings of small Unis lied t*-gather are to bo seen—dangled most cruelly before the passengers’ eyes iu b'«pe of getting money. When once tho native grasps that he will be punished and not re­warded for this, the practice will aoon cease,' and if only one quarter of the hundreds of, tourist* »bo visit the Mile would take the 1 bird away without giving money a great check j would be givoa. I have seen a fellow traveller, a lady, oa more than one occasion administer a sharp stroke with her parasol, startling tho offender so that the bird was dropped, and she was able to take it away. On one of Gpok's steamers, we had a moat humane manager who personally rescued many a tortured victim. Wo were glad to hu-jir him aay that his firm were anxious lor their employes to do all they can to stop it May 1 vesture to oiler one or two suggestions; 1st, that oa the steamer, a notice should be put up asking passengers not to give moo*y fur die birds, 2nd, at the stopping place, of the boats, notices in Arabio should be placed, thru no money will be given for birds brought in such a manner, and that instead jlfcudcr* lay themaeJve* open to punishment; ird,instructions to be given to the police to atop it, Tbis we uever saw them do, otherwise there 1 rould not exist such a blot ou humouity m : ►polls so much the pleasure of a journey up :he grand old Mile.—Yours, etc.,
E. Poole.
